elements.content: A new tetracarboxylic acid derivative of 9,9‘-spirobifluorene (9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylic acid (SBFTCA) (3)) has been prepared and crystallized as a THF solvate (3·THF). Hydrogen bonding between adjacent molecules of 3 results in a (4,4) layer topology and non-interpenetrating AB layer stacking. The topology of 3 gives rise to pores that are occupied by disordered THF molecules. Under hydrothermal conditions, a mixture of 3, methylimidazole, and Co(NO3)2 gives single crystals of a layered network (4) comprising the tetracarboxylate of 3 linked by Co(II) ions. The structure of 4 is similar to that of 3·THF exhibiting an AB motif, with two methylimidazole ligands per cobalt atom occupying the remaining volume.
elements.clean_text: A new tetracarboxylic acid derivative of 9,9‘-spirobifluorene (9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylic acid (SBFTCA) (3)) has been prepared and crystallized as a THF solvate (3⋅THF). Hydrogen bonding between adjacent molecules of 3 results in a (4,4) layer topology and non-interpenetrating AB layer stacking. The topology of 3 gives rise to pores that are occupied by disordered THF molecules. Under hydrothermal conditions, a mixture of 3, methylimidazole, and Co(NO3)2 gives single crystals of a layered network (4) comprising the tetracarboxylate of 3 linked by Co(II) ions. The structure of 4 is similar to that of 3⋅THF exhibiting an AB motif, with two methylimidazole ligands per cobalt atom occupying the remaining volume.

elements.content: The new acid 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylicacid (SBFTCA) has been prepared and the structure of a THF solvate determined. SBFTCA has also been incorporated into a cobalt-containing metal−organic network. Both compounds exhibit AB layered, non-interpenetrating 2-D structures.
elements.clean_text: The new acid 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylicacid (SBFTCA) has been prepared and the structure of a THF solvate determined. SBFTCA has also been incorporated into a cobalt-containing metal-organic network. Both compounds exhibit AB layered, non-interpenetrating 2-D structures.

elements.content: 9,9‘-spirobifluorene (SBF) (Figure ) and its derivatives form an intriguing class of molecules that exhibit a relatively rigid topology and possess electronic characteristics reflective of two independent biphenyl moieties fused at a common spiro center. The topology of SBF gives rise to clefts between the phenyl moieties that can accommodate molecules of an appropriate size and the system can be described electronically as π−σ−π, where conjugation between the orthogonal biphenyl groups is limited. Applications include molecular recognition chemistry, molecular scale optoelectronic devices, catalysis, and during the course of this work, hydrogen-bonded networks that exhibit large porosity.
elements.clean_text: 9,9‘-spirobifluorene (SBF) (Figure ) and its derivatives form an intriguing class of molecules that exhibit a relatively rigid topology and possess electronic characteristics reflective of two independent biphenyl moieties fused at a common spiro center. The topology of SBF gives rise to clefts between the phenyl moieties that can accommodate molecules of an appropriate size and the system can be described electronically as π-σ-π, where conjugation between the orthogonal biphenyl groups is limited. Applications include molecular recognition chemistry, molecular scale optoelectronic devices, catalysis, and during the course of this work, hydrogen-bonded networks that exhibit large porosity.

elements.content: Our motivation for the work reported here was the synthesis of a tetra acid derivative, 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylic acid (SBFTCA), that we envisaged would have a well-defined, relatively rigid topology and could serve as an interesting precursor to metal−organic frameworks and networks. These compounds are of considerable interest because of their promise of rational crystal design and potential application to fields including catalysis, sensors, and gas storage. Significant advances have occurred over recent years, including the preparation of thermally robust achiral and chiral porous frameworks and the preparation of materials exhibiting electromagnetic and optical properties usually associated with condensed inorganic solids. Common organic moieties that link inorganic ions or clusters are derived from carboxylic acids, particularly of commercially available benzene-1,2-di- and 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acids and their derivatives, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Our motivation for the work reported here was the synthesis of a tetra acid derivative, 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylic acid (SBFTCA), that we envisaged would have a well-defined, relatively rigid topology and could serve as an interesting precursor to metal-organic frameworks and networks. These compounds are of considerable interest because of their promise of rational crystal design and potential application to fields including catalysis, sensors, and gas storage. Significant advances have occurred over recent years, including the preparation of thermally robust achiral and chiral porous frameworks and the preparation of materials exhibiting electromagnetic and optical properties usually associated with condensed inorganic solids. Common organic moieties that link inorganic ions or clusters are derived from carboxylic acids, particularly of commercially available benzene-1,2-di- and 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acids and their derivatives, respectively.

elements.content: To increase the diversity of new structures that may exhibit useful properties, there is a need to prepare new linking motifs; here, we report the synthesis of SBFTCA and an initial investigation of its structural chemistry, which includes an example of a cobalt-containing metal−organic network.
elements.clean_text: To increase the diversity of new structures that may exhibit useful properties, there is a need to prepare new linking motifs; here, we report the synthesis of SBFTCA and an initial investigation of its structural chemistry, which includes an example of a cobalt-containing metal-organic network.

elements.content: We envisaged that SBFTCA could potentially be prepared from the known tetrahalide derivatives4a 1a or 1b (Scheme ). The related compound 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘-dicarboxylic acid has been known for many years and is prepared in moderate yield via Friedel Craft's acylation of spirobifluorene. Unfortunately, variations of this route did not work for our target.
elements.clean_text: We envisaged that SBFTCA could potentially be prepared from the known tetrahalide derivatives4a 1a or 1b (Scheme ). The related compound 9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘-dicarboxylic acid has been  known for many years and is prepared in moderate yield via Friedel Craft's acylation of spirobifluorene. Unfortunately, variations of this route did not work for our target.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg060007dh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2006-00007d_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Initial synthetic attempts using metalation of 1a or 1b followed by quenching with carbon dioxide also failed. However, an alternative strategy that proved successful utilized the palladium(II)-catalyzed carboxymethylation of 1b to give tetramethylester 2 (Scheme ). Under our conditions, we found that 1a was unreactive but that 1b gives 2 in 61% yield. Subsequent base hydrolysis and acid workup of 2 gives SBFTCA (3) in 80% yield.
elements.clean_text: Initial synthetic attempts using metalation of 1a or 1b followed by quenching with carbon dioxide also failed. However, an alternative strategy that proved successful utilized the palladium(II)-catalyzed carboxymethylation of 1b to give tetramethylester 2 (Scheme ). Under our conditions, we found that 1a was unreactive but that 1b gives 2 in 61% yield. Subsequent base hydrolysis and acid workup of 2 gives SBFTCA (3) in 80% yield.

elements.content: Compound 3 is isolated as a hydrate and exhibits solubility that we interpret as being dependent on the degree of hydrogen bonding in the solid. When freshly prepared, compound 3 is partially soluble in THF and DMSO but insoluble in all other common organic solvents and water. On standing, solutions of 3 precipitate solvated solids that are very sparingly soluble. However, compound 3 can be completely dissolved on deprotonation in basic aqueous solutions. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy are consistent with the proposed formulation and D 2 d symmetry, and IR spectroscopy reveals a stretch at 1681 cm-1 that is typical of an aromatic carboxylic acid CO group.
elements.clean_text: Compound 3 is isolated as a hydrate and exhibits solubility that we interpret as being dependent on the degree of hydrogen bonding in the solid. When freshly prepared, compound 3 is partially soluble in THF and DMSO but insoluble in all other common organic solvents and water. On standing, solutions of 3 precipitate solvated solids that are very sparingly soluble. However, compound 3 can be completely dissolved on deprotonation in basic aqueous solutions. 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy are consistent with the proposed formulation and D 2  d  symmetry, and IR spectroscopy reveals a stretch at 1681 cm-1 that is typical of an aromatic carboxylic acid CO group.

elements.content: Numerous attempts were made to grow single crystals of 3, but in all cases, crystals were of low quality, diffracted weakly to a low angle, and tended to lose the solvent of crystallization. A further complication was that at lower temperatures, crystals invariably fractured. Nevertheless, a data set of a THF solvate (3·THF) did give a solution that allowed for the constitution of 3·THF to be determined.
elements.clean_text: Numerous attempts were made to grow single crystals of 3, but in all cases, crystals were of low quality, diffracted weakly to a low angle, and tended to lose the solvent of crystallization. A further complication was that at lower temperatures, crystals invariably fractured. Nevertheless, a data set of a THF solvate (3⋅THF) did give a solution that allowed for the constitution of 3⋅THF to be determined.

elements.content: Overall, the structure of 3·THF can be described as containing hydrogen-bonded layers stacked in an AB manner (Figure ). Individual layers are formed from hydrogen bonding between adjacent carboxylic acid groups, where each SBF moiety is coordinated to four nearest neighbors. The layers of 3·THF exhibit a rhombic (4,4) topology (Figure ) of dimension 52.7 Å. The relative orientation of SBF moieties is perhaps best shown by considering a repeat unit of four SBFTCA molecules that can be considered as being a precursor to a layer by assembly in a staggered motif (Figure ). Stacking of layers occurs with overlap of phenyl moieties, but the interlayer distances do not indicate significant arene−arene π-interaction and the geometry at the spiro center is not significantly distorted from that observed for SBF polymorphs or related SBF inclusion compounds. In the absence of interpenetration and because of the topology of 3, voids are present within the layers that are filled with disordered molecules of THF. The structure is reminiscent of 1,1‘-biphenyl-2,2‘,6,6‘-tetracarboxylic acid (BPTCA), which is representative of the only other structurally characterized tetracarboxylic acid that exhibits D 2 d symmetry, comprising homochiral cyclotetrameric units that are hydrogen bonded to adjacent cyclotetramers of opposite chirality. The solvent of crystallization is absent.
elements.clean_text: Overall, the structure of 3⋅THF can be described as containing hydrogen-bonded layers stacked in an AB manner (Figure ). Individual layers are formed from hydrogen bonding between adjacent carboxylic acid groups, where each SBF moiety is coordinated to four nearest neighbors. The layers of 3⋅THF exhibit a rhombic (4,4) topology (Figure ) of dimension 52.7 Å. The relative orientation of SBF moieties is perhaps best shown by considering a repeat unit of four SBFTCA molecules that can be considered as being a precursor to a layer by assembly in a staggered motif (Figure ). Stacking of layers occurs with overlap of phenyl moieties, but the interlayer distances do not indicate significant arene-arene π-interaction and the geometry at the spiro center is not significantly distorted from that observed for SBF polymorphs or related SBF inclusion compounds. In the absence of interpenetration and because of the topology of 3, voids are present within the layers that are filled with disordered molecules of THF. The structure is reminiscent of 1,1‘-biphenyl-2,2‘,6,6‘-tetracarboxylic acid (BPTCA), which is representative of the only other structurally characterized tetracarboxylic acid that exhibits D 2  d  symmetry, comprising homochiral cyclotetrameric units that are hydrogen bonded to adjacent cyclotetramers of opposite chirality. The solvent of crystallization is absent.

elements.content: The structure was refined with a THF:3 ratio of 1:1, although bulk elemental analysis was not reproducible because of solvent loss. However, the THF:3 ratio was estimated by 1H NMR spectroscopy of 3·THF dissolved in a basic solution containing an internal reference. An average composition 3(THF)0.9 was obtained that is broadly consistent with the crystallographic study. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was also performed and showed a steady mass loss of 12% to 300 °C that corresponds to the irreversible loss of 0.95 equiv of THF, and this material does not uptake a significant quantity of H2 at 25 °C and 1 bar. At higher temperatures, a plateau is observed before decomposition and rapid mass loss above 375 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction indicated that desolvated 3 is essentially amorphous.
elements.clean_text: The structure was refined with a THF:3 ratio of 1:1, although bulk elemental analysis was not reproducible because of solvent loss. However, the THF:3 ratio was estimated by 1H NMR spectroscopy of 3⋅THF dissolved in a basic solution containing an internal reference. An average composition 3(THF)0.9 was obtained that is  broadly consistent with the crystallographic study. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was also performed and showed a steady mass loss of 12% to 300 °C that corresponds to the irreversible loss of 0.95 equiv of THF, and this material does not uptake a significant quantity of H2 at 25 °C and 1 bar. At higher temperatures, a plateau is observed before decomposition and rapid mass loss above 375 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction indicated that desolvated 3 is essentially amorphous.

elements.content: We then attempted to use compound 3 as a tetracarboxylate linking motif in a metal-containing structure. To date, most hydrothermal reactions between metal sources, 3, and bases have not led to the formation of single crystalline metal−organic networks, although PXRD indicates products of good crystallinity. However, hydrothermal reaction between 3, Co(NO3)2, the organic base methylimidazole (MeIm), and water in a 1:2:8:1950 3:Co:MeIm:H2O ratio gave purple single crystals of the metal−organic network 4 in 85% yield. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of 4 gave a refined composition corresponding to 2:4:1 Co:MeIm:9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylate, which is consistent with bulk elemental analysis. TGA shows that 4 is thermally robust and exhibits no significant mass loss up to approximately 300 °C, but above 375 °C, rapid mass loss occurs because of decomposition.
elements.clean_text: We then attempted to use compound 3 as a tetracarboxylate linking motif in a metal-containing structure. To date, most hydrothermal reactions between metal sources, 3, and bases have not led to the formation of single crystalline metal-organic networks, although PXRD indicates products of good crystallinity. However, hydrothermal reaction between 3, Co(NO3)2, the organic base methylimidazole (MeIm), and water in a 1:2:8:1950 3:Co:MeIm:H2O ratio gave purple single crystals of the metal-organic network 4 in 85% yield. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of 4 gave a refined composition corresponding to 2:4:1 Co:MeIm:9,9‘-spirobifluorene-2,2‘,7,7‘-tetracarboxylate, which is consistent with bulk elemental analysis. TGA shows that 4 is thermally robust and exhibits no significant mass loss up to approximately 300 °C, but above 375 °C, rapid mass loss occurs because of decomposition.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit, two pseudotetrahedral cobalt atoms are each coordinated to two MeIm ligands and two carboxylate moieties, as shown in Figure . In common with 3·THF, the geometry at the spiro center of 4 is not significantly distorted and exhibits angles within 1° of 3·THF. The bonding of the carboxylate moieties to Co atoms are between η1 and η2, as judged by Co−O and C−O bond lengths and IR spectroscopy. The carboxylate incorporating C(29) is essentially η1 and a stretch at 1646 cm-1 is assigned to the carbonyl vibration of this group. The remaining carboxylate groups have greater η2 character and account for stretches observed between 1590 and 1540 cm-1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In the asymmetric unit, two pseudotetrahedral cobalt atoms are each coordinated to two MeIm ligands and two carboxylate moieties, as shown in Figure . In common with 3⋅THF, the geometry at the spiro center of 4 is not significantly distorted and exhibits angles within 1° of 3⋅THF. The bonding of the carboxylate moieties to Co atoms are between η1 and η2, as judged by Co-O and C-O bond lengths and IR spectroscopy. The carboxylate incorporating C(29) is essentially η1 and a stretch at 1646 cm-1 is assigned to the carbonyl vibration of this group. The remaining carboxylate groups have greater η2 character and account for stretches observed between 1590 and 1540 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: Similarly to 3·THF, compound 4 also exhibits a layered structure with AB stacking. Individual layers comprise SBF moieties coordinated via Co atoms (Figure ). The remaining volume not shown in Figure is occupied by MeIm ligands that penetrate adjacent layers. (Figure ). The shortest interlayer Co−Co distance is 7.2 Å; there does not appear to be any significant directional interlayer bonding, although SBF phenyl moieties are aligned facially between adjacent layers with a distance of 4.2 Å (Figure ). Other reported structures derived from cobalt and carboxylate linkers exhibit Co−O bond lengths similar to those observed in 4, including layered structures observed using aromatic linkers containing four carboxylic acid functionalities such as 1,2,4,5-benzene tetracarboxylic acid and 3,3‘,4,4‘-benzophenone-tetracarboxylate.
elements.clean_text: Similarly to 3⋅THF, compound 4 also exhibits a layered structure with AB stacking. Individual layers comprise SBF moieties coordinated via Co atoms (Figure ). The remaining volume not shown in Figure  is occupied by MeIm ligands that penetrate adjacent layers. (Figure ). The shortest interlayer Co-Co distance is 7.2 Å; there does not appear to be any significant directional interlayer bonding, although SBF phenyl moieties are aligned facially between adjacent layers with a distance of 4.2 Å (Figure ). Other reported structures derived from cobalt and carboxylate linkers exhibit Co-O bond lengths similar to those observed in 4, including layered structures observed using aromatic linkers containing four carboxylic acid functionalities such as 1,2,4,5-benzene tetracarboxylic acid and 3,3‘,4,4‘-benzophenone-tetracarboxylate.

elements.content: AB layer structure of4 viewed along the b axis. (a) MeIm ligands and hydrogen atoms are not shown. (b) All atoms are shown.
elements.clean_text: 6  AB layer structure of4 viewed along the b axis. (a) MeIm ligands and hydrogen atoms are not shown. (b) All atoms are shown.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 4 were performed between 4 and 300 K for both zero-field- and field (2 T)-cooled magnetization. The data are essentially consistent with simple paramagnetic behavior with an average effective magnetic moment of 4.07 μB per Co atom, characteristic of a Co(II) ion in pseudotetrahedral symmetry.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 4 were performed between 4 and 300 K for both zero-field- and field (2 T)-cooled magnetization. The data are essentially consistent with simple paramagnetic behavior with an average effective magnetic moment of 4.07 μB per Co atom, characteristic of a Co(II) ion in pseudotetrahedral symmetry.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized a new tetracarboxylic acid with unusual D 2 d symmetry that has been used to prepare the first in a new class of layered metal−organic solids incorporating the SBF motif. The structures described here indicate that two-dimensional layered structures may be prevalent when SBFTCA is used as a linker and that single crystals of metal−organic networks incorporating SBFTCA can be prepared using hydrothermal techniques.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have synthesized a new tetracarboxylic acid with unusual D 2  d  symmetry that has been used to prepare the first in a new class of layered metal-organic solids incorporating the SBF motif. The structures described here indicate that two-dimensional layered structures may be prevalent when SBFTCA is used as a linker and that single crystals of metal-organic networks incorporating SBFTCA can be prepared using hydrothermal techniques.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic information (CIF) files for compounds 3·THF and 4. General experimental procedures and IR for compounds 2−4. 1H NMR and TGA for compound 3·THF and magnetic data for compound 4. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
